Abby Elliott, who plays Sugar, has a family home in Harpswell and has earned praise on the show about Maine food. Their connections highlight local Maine businesses featured in the show and help bring attention to the region's culinary scene.

stories.headline: Gov. Mills delays decisions on dozens of bills, including ban on untraceable firearms
stories.summary: Governor Janet Mills is delaying action on numerous bills passed by lawmakers that included measures such as banning untraceable firearms and expanding exclusive rights to operate online gambling. Mills has allowed 10 days from when lawmakers gave final passage for her to act, but the deadline passed with no decision. The delayed bills will remain unsigned until the legislature reconvenes, which is unlikely before January. This delay allows Mills to fully evaluate legal and constitutional issues with the proposed laws.

stories.headline: Trump planning price hike for foreign visitors at Acadia, other national parks
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's administration is set to increase entrance fees at national parks for foreign visitors, including Acadia National Park. The order, announced by the Secretary of the Interior, calls for increased staffing and budget cuts which would lead to higher visitor fees to compensate. The goal is to shift some costs to nonresidents and foreign tourists who currently pay less or no fees at certain parks. The hike would affect other landmarks in Maine beyond Acadia, such as Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument and Saint Croix Island International Historic Site.
people: Secretary of the Interior Doug Burgum

stories.headline: New Maine laws will change electricity billing, formalize state’s energy goals
stories.summary: Governor Janet Mills has signed dozens of new laws related to Maine's utilities and energy markets aimed at improving electricity billing and promoting renewable energy. Among the changes are updates to the state's energy billing procedures, new benchmarks to boost renewable energy adoption including small rooftop solar panels, and changes to Maine's net energy billing program that affect credits for electricity produced by small renewable systems. Starting in January, new billing rules will impose fees for power systems producing over 1 megawatt, designed to offset costs retail ratepayers would bear otherwise. The state also plans a successor program for net energy billing.

stories.headline: 20-year-old deported after ICE check-in
stories.summary: Pascual Pedro, a 20-year-old construction worker and West Liberty High School graduate, was deported to Guatemala just after the Fourth of July weekend. Pedro had been living in Iowa for seven years. His deportation occurred shortly after a routine check-in with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, leaving the local community shocked. His attorney and a faith-based migrant rights group have spoken out about the case.

stories.headline: Texas region long prone to flooding
stories.summary: The catastrophic flooding in the Hill Country of south-central Texas on July 4 occurred in an area known as 'flash flood alley,' which is prone to fast and furious flooding due to extreme rainfalls. Experts say this region, including San Antonio, Dallas, Austin and Waco, has a historical and prehistoric pattern of flash flooding intensified by moisture from the Gulf of Mexico. The flooding was blamed by scientists on extreme rain, with more than 10 inches falling around 4 a.m., which overwhelmed the Guadalupe River.

stories.headline: Brownell dies: Businessman, patron of the arts was 85
stories.summary: Frank Brownell III, a successful gunsmithing businessman and patron of the arts, passed away at the age of 85. Brownell died six days before his 86th birthday after a long illness. He was involved in running the family-owned Brownells retail store and held leadership roles in the company until his death. A visitation and Masonic service have been announced to honor his memory.

stories.headline: Burke released early from federal prison
stories.summary: Former Chicago Alderman Ed Burke has been released early from federal prison after serving the majority of his sentence for a corruption case. Burke, who had been expected to serve over a year of community confinement next year, was transferred from prison to a lower-security facility last month and will now complete supervised release early. He was convicted of shaking down city contractors and was sentenced to 81 months in prison.

stories.headline: State fines, reprimands abortion provider
stories.summary: A Champaign abortion provider has been reprimanded and fined by the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation for leaving half a fetus inside a patient during a procedure. Dr. Keith Reisinger-Kindle of Equity Clinic is required to pay a $5,000 fine and complete 20 hours of continuing medical education for failing to evaluate the patient properly, which resulted in hospitalization. The disciplinary action is related to a May 16 complaint, and a related negligence lawsuit is still pending.

stories.headline: Gang feud resurfaces in River North shooting
stories.summary: A drive-by shooting outside a lounge on Chicago Avenue left four dead and 14 others injured, marking one of the worst attacks in recent city memory. Police and City Hall officials confirmed the shooting targeted specific victims tied to neighborhood gang activity, related to an ongoing feud among Chicago drill rapper Mello Buckzz’s group NLMIB and rival South Side gangs. Investigators are gathering video evidence and seeking information from associates of the involved parties.

stories.headline: Militant attack kills five Israeli soldiers in Gaza
stories.summary: Five Israeli soldiers were killed in an attack in northern Gaza, as Israel's military stated. The incident may heighten pressure on Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to strike a deal for a ceasefire amid ongoing conflict. Senior Israeli officials noted the high percentage of details leaked about a possible agreement, though confidentiality remains a concern. This attack is part of escalating violence including a recent airstrike in northern Lebanon targeting a senior Hamas militant.

stories.headline: Flood alerts under scrutiny
stories.summary: After weekend flash floods devastated parts of Texas, residents in Austin area criticized the flood warnings as late or insufficiently clear. The flood caused deadly and missing persons incidents, with some locals saying emergency messages urging search for higher ground arrived too late. Officials in Travis County acknowledged confusion and promised a study of the alert system.

stories.headline: Kerr County long sought system for flood notice
stories.summary: Nearly a decade ago, Kerr County officials recognized the need for a new flood warning system on the Guadalupe River due to climate and terrain changes. Earlier systems installed in the 1980s were no longer adequate. Local officials have been trying to push for an upgrade to improve future flood alerts and reduce disaster impact.

stories.headline: Abbott: Up to 161 could be missing
stories.summary: Texas Governor Greg Abbott confirmed that up to 161 people could still be missing in Kerr County following deadly flash floods. The death toll has risen to 94 with ongoing search efforts. Officials face criticism over the adequacy of warnings about the rising Guadalupe River and the protection of vulnerable residents.

stories.headline: Victim: ‘We’re basically on our own’
stories.summary: Travis County residents are struggling to recover from severe flooding, with damaged homes and lost belongings. Residents like Miranda Basey and her husband Larry describe the desperation of the flood and say they are relying on Facebook posts and community help rather than officials. Emergency responders continue cleanup and efforts to reach missing people amid widespread property damage.

stories.headline: Cannabis company to close 20 dispensaries in Michigan
stories.summary: A large cannabis company in Michigan, Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification letter filed with the Michigan Department of Labor and Economic Opportunity, announced plans to close 20 dispensaries across the state. The closures are part of a broader plan as the company ceases all operations in Michigan, affecting more than 230 employees. Dispensaries affected include locations in Ann Arbor, Detroit, Jackson, Kalamazoo, and several other cities. The company is also planning to close cultivation and processing facilities in several states, with the total number of affected employees nearing 1,200 nationwide by mid-2026.

stories.headline: Camp operators discuss safety plans after Texas floods
stories.summary: Following devastating floods in Texas that killed more than two dozen campers and counselors at Camp Mystic, summer camp operators across the region are reviewing and discussing their safety and emergency preparedness plans. While some families have been reassured by updated emergency measures, concerns remain about risks such as flooding and even active shooters. The American Camp Association and camp operators emphasize the importance of plans for emergencies, including communication and safety protocols, to better protect children during camp activities.

stories.headline: American kids are growing increasingly unhealthy
stories.summary: A new study reveals that over the past 17 years, the health of U.S. children has significantly declined. Chronic diseases, depression, and mental health problems are on the rise. The study highlights that American children are around 1.8 times more likely to die than kids in other high-income countries from 2007-2022. Factors contributing to this decline include increased vulnerability, reduced physical activity, and broader societal changes affecting children's well-being. The study was co-authored by experts from Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and UW Medicine in Seattle, presenting a comprehensive overview of worsening child health trends in the U.S.
people: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

stories.headline: $34M for Sixth Street gone under Trump bill
stories.summary: A $36.6 million allocation for Sixth Street reconstruction, intended to convert a 2.6-mile section to a 'complete street,' has been rescinded under a Trump administration tax cut and spending bill adopted by Republicans. The funds were part of a neighborhood access and equity grant program, and their removal raises uncertainty about whether Milwaukee can complete any part of the plan alone. Milwaukee Mayor Cavalier Johnson expressed concerns about the impacts on traffic safety, job creation, and local economic activity.

stories.headline: Report disagrees with Dugan argument
stories.summary: A federal magistrate judge issued a report recommending against dismissing the obstruction charge against Milwaukee County Circuit Judge Hannah Dugan. The report states that the prosecution and Dugan's team should resolve differences about facts at trial. The magistrate judge found the judicial immunity argument flawed, countering claims by Dugan's lawyers that the federal prosecution is improper and amounts to federal overreach.

stories.headline: Court allows conversion therapy ban
stories.summary: The Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled 4-3 that a key legislative committee cannot indefinitely block agencies’ rules, including a state agency rule banning conversion therapy for LGBTQ+ people. This ruling clears the way for the state to implement the ban, limiting the Legislature and a committee's power over administrative rules. The majority opinion deemed indefinitely blocking the rule unconstitutional and emphasized the Legislature's rulemaking scope under the constitution.
